questions.text: Which of the following pair for rapid antigen detection test for parasites is inappropriate?
questions.solution:
Option C - RAT (Rapid antigen detection test) is a common procedure for diagnosis of parasitic infection employing species-specific antigen in which monoclonal antibodies against the specific antigen are bound to the membrane. Lateral flow of the sample will result in binding of antigen to specific monoclonal antibodies resulting in color band formation. pLDH is an antigen present in all species of Plasmodia. It is not a species-specific antigen. Species specific antigen in P.falciparum is pHRP-2.


Option A,B & D - are examples of diagnosis of parasitic infection using their species-specific antigen.

Reference: Paniker's textbook of Parasitology - 8th Edition, Pg. No. -7

questions.text: A person who has taken bath dips in the holy water of a river with his nose and mouth closed by fingers, now afraid of acquiring one of parasitic infections. He should screen himself for which parasitic infection if symptoms develop.
questions.solution:
Option - D - infective forms of many parasites are present in contaminated water. They either enter through direct skin penetration (S.haematobium), nasal mucosal penetration (Naegleria fowleri), ingestion of cyclops (D.medinensis) or ingestion of aquatic vegetation (F.hepatica).

Free cercariae is an infective form of S.haematobium in contaminated water. When it comes in contact with skin it directly penetrates and develop in blood vessels.

Metacercaria which encyst in aquatic vegetation are infective forms of F.hepatica. When a person ingest this contaminated vegetation containing metacercaria, cercariae released in the intestine develop in liver. This is not the case here as the person has not ingested vegetation.

Cyclops containing infective 3rd stage larva is an infective form for D.medinensis. Person who ingest contaminated water containing cyclops, larva will hatch out and develop into subcutaneous tissue. This is not the case here as the person has not ingested water.

Trophozoites of N.fowleri survive in water for long and when a susceptible person takes bath in infected water, they enter through penetrating nasal mucosa. This is not the case here as the person has closed his nostrils.

Reference: Paniker's textbook of Parasitology - 8th Edition, Pg. No. -145

questions.text: Which of the following require two intermediate hosts for completion of life cycle?
questions.solution:
Option B - C.sinensis is a trematode which has man as definitive host and snail and fish are two intermediate hosts. There are few parasites which require 2 intermediate hosts. These are: D.latum ( cyclops & fish), P.westermani (snail & crab/crayfish) and Fasciola species ( snail & plants ). Most trematodes except Schistosomes which require two intermediate hosts for completion of life cycle.

Option A- Only 1 intermediate host - cow

Option C- Culex mosquito acts as a vector as well as intermediate host

Option D- Only 1 intermediate host - cyclops

Reference: Paniker's textbook of Parasitology - 8th Edition, Pg. No. -4

choices.text: Presence of trophozoite with ingested RBC

questions.text: Best way to differentiate amoebic dysentery stool from bacillary dysentery stool in microscopy is -
questions.solution:
Option D - The only confirmatory way to diagnose E.histolytica infection (amoebic dysentery) is presence of trophozoites with ingested RBCs. Macrophage can be present in amoebic as well as bacillary dysentery. Though characteristically present in clumps, RBC's can be present discrete and it is very difficult to identify type of dysentery based on arrangement of RBCs as its not very specific. Charcot-Leyden crystals are present in amoebic dysentery but it is also present in other parasitic infection and allergic conditions.

Reference: Paniker's textbook of Parasitology - 8th Edition, Pg. No. -20

questions.text: A 32-year-old emigrant from West Bengal, complains of fever and weight loss for the past 3 weeks. Laboratory tests revealed anemia and leukopenia . Multiple blood cultures for bacteria and fungi were negative. p24 antigen test for HIV was negative. A bone marrow biopsy was performed and a Giemsa stained smear revealed the following intracellular parasite in the picture shown. What is the likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Option A - These are intracellular amastigotes of L.donovani. They are also called as L-D bodies and are important histological findings for diagnosis of Kala-azar. Residing in an endemic area (West Bengal), fever and weight loss are clues for diagnosis, which however can also occur in HIV. However, a highly sensitive p24 antigen test which is usually performed early in infection (window period) before development of antibodies, is negative here excluding diagnosis. Symptomatology along with anemia, leukopenia and a positive bone marrow smear are clues to diagnosis. P.falciparum usually does not cause weight loss, T.brucei causes sleeping sickness and T.cruzi causes acute and chronic chagas disease.

Reference: Paniker's textbook of Parasitology - 8th Edition, Pg. No. -59

questions.text: Chronic infection with which of the following haemoflagellate is associated with megacolon :
questions.solution:
Option B - In chronic phase of infection by T.cruzi, cellular destruction and fibrosis of muscles and nerves that control tone of hollow organs like heart, esophagus and colon occurs leading to cardiomyopathy, megaesophagus and megacolon.

Reference: Paniker's textbook of Parasitology - 8th Edition, Pg. No. -50

choices.text: Wet mount examination for characteristic jerky motility
Gram stain demonstration of intracellular diplococci
Demonstration of clue cells by gram stain

questions.text: A young adult female having profuse yellowish green offensive vaginal discharge, dysuria and dyspareunia has come to the STI clinic. Upon physical examination, mucosa has an erythematous, punctate and papilliform appearance. (Strawberry mucosa). Which rapid test/technique helps to find out etiological agent.
questions.solution:
Option A - This is a case of Trichomonas vaginalis infection which can be diagnosed by examining saline wet mount of vaginal discharge. As characteristic jerky and twitching motility of trophozoite is rapidly lost outside the body, it should be examined immediately upon collection. Offensive yellowish green profuse discharge along with Strawberry mucosa is characteristic of infection.

Other causes of vaginitis are : fungal Candida species (demonstrated by KOH preparation) in which thick, white, curdy or cheesy discharge is produced. Bacterial by Gardnerella vaginalis (demonstrated by clue cells) has profuse, thin, watery discharge with fishy smell. N.gonorrhoeae typically causes cervicitis and not vaginitis. (Gram stain demonstration of intracellular diplococci).

Reference: Paniker's textbook of Parasitology - 8th Edition, Pg. No. -37

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for Mycoplasma pneumoniae causing Pneumonia?
questions.solution:
For mycoplasma pneumoniae:

  • Macrolides are drug of choice (oral azithromycin, 500 mg on day 1, then 250 mg on days 2 to 5)
  • Alternative drugs are as follows: Doxycycline, Respiratory fluoroquinolones such as levofloxacin, moxifloxacin and gemifloxacin (not ciprofloxacin).

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd edition, page no: 620

questions.text: Match following trematode with their mode of infection -
questions.solution:
• Option A - Cercariae or metacercariae are infective forms for trematode infections. There are various ways by which they enter our body. Cercariae of Schistosomes, in water directly penetrates skin, while in other trematodes, these cercariae encyst in various aquatic hosts like vegetation (F.hepatica), fish (C.sinensis) and Crab (P.westermani) and ingestion of these metacercariae leads to infections.

Reference: Paniker's textbook of Parasitology - 8th Edition, Pg. No. 143

questions.text: Which is the main receptor for HIV to bind to CD4+ cells?
questions.solution:
• Gp120 is the main receptor for HIV to bind to CD4+ cells.
  • Gp41 is the fusion protein
  • P24 is a core antigen
  • P18 is a matrix antigen

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd edition, page 326

questions.text: Kapil is a known case of HIV in the past 3 years. Recently, he has been non-compliant with HAART and now presents with focal neurological deficits, headache and 2 episodes of seizures. Upon imaging, the following lesions were observed. What is the prophylaxis of this illness?
questions.solution:
• The above radiological image along with the clinical features suggests cerebral toxoplasmosis, which is a reactivation of T. Gondii cysts in the brain.
  • It presents with fever, focal neurological deficits, seizures, headache etc.
  • Imaging shows multiple ring enhancing lesions with severe edema.
  • Prophylaxis for cerebral toxoplasmosis is started at CD cell count of <100cells/uL and cotrimoxazole is given.

Treatment: is with cotrimoxazole + folinic acid for 6 weeks.

Clindamycin is given for treatment in Sulfa allergy.

Clotrimazole is an antifungal.

Reference: Neurological Manifestations of Human Immunodeficiency Virus Infection in Adults Joseph Jankovic MD, in Bradley and Daroff's Neurology in Clinical Practice, 2022

questions.text: Identify the image:
questions.solution:
This image is of Ebola

It belongs to family filoviridae.

Spread through contact with infected patient secretions.

Biosafety level 4 should be maintain

Investigation of choice - Real time PCR.

choices.text: It is coccoid, Gram negative bacillus
Most human infections are caused by serovar 2a or 2b

questions.text: A 70 year old male presented with fever, vomiting and neck rigidity. Patient's blood picture shows monocytosis. Organism cultivated from CSF gives positive Anton test, which one statement is incorrect?
questions.solution:
The causative organism of the given clinical condition is Listeria monocytogenes. It is a gram positive coccobacilli.

Most human infections are caused by serovar 2a or 2b.

Listeria shows tumbling motility at 25 C but non motile at 37 C(called differential motility which is due to temp dependent flagella expression)

It is catalase positive organism

ANTON TEST- Listeria culture is put into eyes of rabbit and rabbit develops keratoconjuctivitis.

Selective culture media for listeria -PALCAM agar

Ampicillin is drug of choice for Listerosis.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and paniker's textbook of microbiology 10th ed. Pg.402,403

questions.text: Which stain is used for fungi
questions.solution:
Fungal elements stained using

  • Potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation
  • Gram stain
  • India ink and nigrosin stains
  • Calcofluor white stain
  • Histopathological stains like
  • Periodic acid schiff(PAS)stain
  • Gomori methenamine silver stain
  • Mucicarmine
  • Masson fontana stain
  • H & E stain
  • Lactophenol cotton blue (LPCB)

Reference: Sastry 3rd edition pg. 116.

Reference: Ananthnarayan and Paniker's textbook of Microbiology 12th edition pg no. 89-90

questions.text: Which of the following is true about dimorphic fungi?
questions.solution:
• They exist as molds (hyphal form) in the environment at ambient temperature (25°C) and as yeasts in human tissues at body temperature (37°C).

Examples

  • Histoplasma capsulatum
  • Blastomyces dermatitidis
  • Coccidioides immitis
  • Paracoccidioides brasiliensis
  • Talaromyces marneffei
  • Sporothrix schenckii.

Reference: Sastry 3rd ed chapter 6

Reference: Ananthnarayan and Paniker's textbook of Microbiology 12th edition pg no. 86

questions.text: A patient is suffering from fungal infection which has barrel shaped Arthroconidia and spherules. Which is the disease caused by causative agent
questions.solution:
• Coccidioidomycosis (also called desert rheumatism or Valley fever or California fever, San Joaquin valley fever)
  • Paracoccidioidomycosis (also known as South American blastomycosis, Lutz-Splendore-de Almeida disease)
  • Blastomycosis (also known as North American blastomycosis or Gilchrist's disease or Chicago disease)
  • Histoplasmosis is a systemic granulomatous disease caused by a dimorphic fungus, Histoplasma capsulatum. The species name is a misnomer as it is not capsulated. It was first reported by Samuel Darling (1905), hence is also known as Darling's disease.

Reference: Sastry 3rd ed pg. 379 to 383

Reference: Ananthnarayan and Paniker's textbook of Microbiology 12th edition pg no. 411

questions.text: Ectothrix is due to
questions.solution:
• Endothrix - Arthrospore formation occurs within the hair completely filling the hair shaft, Example: T. tonsurans T. violaceum & T.schoenleinii
  • Ectothrix - Arthrospore formation occurs on the outer surface of hair shaft. Examples: T.rubrum, M.gypseum, M audounii , M.canis , T. mentagrophytes, T.verrucosum

A Ectothrix B Endothrix

Reference: Ananthnarayan and Paniker's textbook of Microbiology 12th edition pg no. 601

Reference: Jagdish Chander 3/e p135, Ananthanarayan 9/e p598, 8/e p 606

questions.text: Buruli ulcer is caused by
questions.solution:
• Buruli ulcer is caused by atypical mycobacteria named as Mycobacteria ulcerans
  • Mycobacteria ulcerans-
    • It is a water borne skin pathogen which is categorised under non - photochromogens ( Runyon's classification )
    • This cause lesions which are typically painless ulcers and nodules.
    • It has narrow temp. range of 31° - 34° C

Reference: Ananthanarayan and paniker's textbook of microbiology 10th ed. Pg.368

questions.text: Latex agglutination study of the antigen in CSF helps in the diagnosis of
questions.solution:
• Cryptococcal antigens can be detected in CSF, serum and urine by latex agglutination test.
    • Antigen titre in CSF stays for longer duration and is directly proportional to mortality of the patients.

Reference: Jagdish Chander 3/e p306, Harrison 18/e p1651,17/e p1252

Reference: Ananthnarayan and Paniker's textbook of Microbiology 12th edition pg no. 473

questions.text: Which of the following is a single stranded DNA virus?
questions.solution:
• Parvovirus is the only single stranded DNA virus, while all other DNA viruses are double stranded.
  • Parvoviruses are the smallest viruses, icosahedral in shape and non-enveloped.
  • Parvovirus is transmitted most commonly by respiratory route, followed by blood exchange and transplacental route.
  • Parvovirus infects red cell progenitors and is responsible for:
  1. Fifth day disease/Erythema infectiosum - shows slapped cheek appearance
  2. Pure Red Cell Aplasia
    C. Non-immune Hydrops Fetalis
    D. Aplastic Crisis - seen in Sickle Cell patients
  3. Polyathropathy in pregnant females

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd Edition, Page Number 80

choices.text: Attachment Penetration biosynthesis maturation Uncoating Release
Attachment Penetration Uncoating biosynthesis maturation Release

questions.text: What is the correct sequence of viral replication?
questions.solution:
Viral Replication passes through six steps.

  1. Attachment: occurs via specific receptors (E.g., HIV attaches via gp120 to CD4 receptor)
  2. Penetration: via fusion, nucleocapsid enters while envelope stays outside
  3. Uncoating: by action of lysosomal enzymes, nucleic acid is released in cytoplasm
  4. Biosynthesis: synthesis of nucleic acid, capsid protein, enzymes, regulatory proteins
  5. Release: via BUDDING in enveloped viruses and LYSIS in non-enveloped virus

Site of replication:

DNA viruses- in nucleus (except Poxvirus, occurs in cytoplasm)

RNA viruses- in cytoplasm (except Orthomyxovirus, occurs in nucleus)


Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd Edition, Page Number 80

questions.text:
Which of the following viruses have segmented RNA?
1. Corona
2. Bunya
3. Arena
4. Filo
5. Rhabdo
6. Calici
7. Orthomyxovirus
8. Picorna
9. Reo
10.Toga
questions.solution:
RNA viruses which have segmented RNA are:

Arenavirus: 2 segments Bunyavirus: 3 segments Orthomyxovirus: 8 segments Reovirus: 10-11 segments

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd Edition, Page Number 80

choices.text: It is transmitted by Ixodes tick.
Erythema chronicum migrans may be a clinical feature
Borrelia recurrentis is the aetiological agent.

questions.text: The following are true regarding Lyme's Disease, except:
questions.solution:
• Lyme disease is caused by Borrelia Burgdorferi
  • The vector for this disease is Ixodes tick.
  • Rodents act as natural hosts
  • Erythema chronicum migrans may be a clinical feature

questions.text: A 29-year-old truck driver, Paramjit, presented to Dermatology OPD with an itch rash growing on his torso, which is shown in photo below. On examination, his temperature was 100.4°F and BP was 120/80 along with generalized lymphadenopathy. On rapid test, it was suggestive for HIV positive. What is the causative organism for this?
questions.solution:
• Above image is highly suggestive for Kaposi Sarcoma, caused by HHV8.
  • Kaposi Sarcoma is an AIDS-defining illness, in which a tumor grows in skin, lymph nodes, internal organs or mucous membranes as red/purple/brown patches.
  • HHV8 belongs to subfamily of Herpesvirus and infects B-cells.
  • It commonly infects immunocompromised individuals, causing
  1. Kaposi Sarcoma
  2. Primary Effusion Lymphoma
  3. Castleman Disease

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd Edition, Page Number 550

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of low-grade fever and painful lesions on her left index finger. Two weeks ago, she had a painful rash on the right labia majora that resolved without treatment. Physical examination shows tender lymphadenopathy of the left epitrochlear and right inguinal region. A photograph of the left index finger is shown. Which organism is responsible for this?
questions.solution:
• This woman has herpetic whitlow, which manifests with a painful, vesicular rash on the fingers which is caused by herpes simplex virus (HSV).
  • HSV is an enveloped virus with a linear dsDNA structure.
  • The envelope is a lipid bilayer around an icosahedral capsid that contains viral glycoproteins and proteins from the host cell; it helps the virus fuse with and infect host cells.
  • Unlike most other enveloped viruses, which use lipids from host cell plasma membranes to build their envelopes, the herpesviruses use lipids from host cell nuclear membranes.
  • Because immune cells do not typically attack host cell nuclei, the envelope aids in viral evasion of the immune response.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd Edition, Page Number 550

questions.text: Identify the test?
questions.solution:
Fom the diagram 'A' bacteria is mostly likely to be Group B streptococcus(Streptococcus Agalactiae ).B bacteria is mostly likely streptococcus pyogenes which do not show the CAMP test ( Christie atkins munch Peterson ) in which enhanced B hemolysis test is seen In group b streptococci which shows negative results

→CAT states for cold agglutination test done for mycoplasma

→SAT states for standard agglutination test done for brucella

MAT ( micro agglutination test ) is done for leptospira

Reference: Ananthanarayan 10th ed Pg 219

questions.text: A patient is presented with rashes all over the body sparing palm and soles. There is no history of animal exposure in this patient. Which of the following bacterial species is most likely the causative agent?
questions.solution: Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd edition, page no: 311

questions.text: A 65-year old male patient presented with complaints of fever, dry cough, dyspena and bouts of diarrhoea since 3 days. His temperature was 102.3°F, BP was 90/66 mm-Hg. On examination, B/L creps are heard. Lab tests were as follows: Hb 13.3g% WBC 13000/cumm Plat 2,00,000/cumm S. Na 130 mEq/L S. K 4.2 mEq/L He worked at a nearby dairy unit. Similar complaints were observed in his neighbors, who all share central AC units. Which lab method will help you identify the organism causing this disease?
questions.solution:
• The given scenario fits with Legionnaires' Disease, which is caused by gram-negative organism Legionella.
  • Legionnaire's disease is classically seen as atypical pneumonia (explains fever, dry cough and dyspnea) with diarrhea (explains hypotension) and hyponatremia. Usually CXR shows pulmonary infiltrates.
  • Most common route of spread is Aspiration.
  • Although, Legionella is also spread by contaminated AC units, nebulisers, humidifiers. There is no man-to-man transmission.
  • Lab techniques used to identify Legionella are:
    • Buffered Charcoal Yeast Agar (BCYE agar)
    • Urinary Antigen Test
    • ELISA/ PCR
  • Other Options:
    • B: PLET media is used to identify Bacillus anthrax.
    • C: SAT is used for identification of Brucella.
    • D: H. pylori infection is diagnosed by Urea Breath Test.
    • E: PPLO agar helps in identifying Mycoplasma.
  • Takeaway Message: Think about Legionella when pneumonia + diarrhea, AC units, multiple exposures are involved.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd edition, page 622

questions.text: Which is the only shigella species which does not test positive for the following biochemical reaction?
questions.solution:
The given biochemical reaction is the catalase reaction. This enzyme detoxifies hydrogen peroxide by breaking it down into water and oxygen gas. The bubbles resulting from production of oxygen gas clearly indicate a catalase positive result. All shigella are catalase positive except shigella dysenteriae type 1.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd edition, page 400

questions.text: A patient with complains of a step ladder pattern of fever for 4 days and rose spots comes to the medicine OPD. Which of the following is the best investigation ?
questions.solution:
Let's justify each option:

Option A) Blood:

  • Blood cultures are commonly performed to detect bacterial or fungal infections in the bloodstream.
  • They are often used as the first-line diagnostic test for patients with fever of unknown origin or suspected sepsis.
  • Blood cultures can detect a wide range of pathogens that may be causing the fever, including bacteria and fungi.
  • However, they may not always yield positive results, especially if the pathogen is not present in the bloodstream or if the patient is receiving antibiotics that suppress bacterial growth.

Option B) Stool and Urine:

  • Stool and urine cultures are essential for diagnosing gastrointestinal and urinary tract infections, respectively.
  • They are typically used when the clinical presentation and symptoms suggest these specific types of infections.
  • Stool cultures are important for identifying enteric pathogens responsible for conditions like infectious diarrhea.
  • Urine cultures can help diagnose urinary tract infections (UTIs).
  • While these cultures are valuable for their respective purposes, they may not be the primary choice for investigating a step ladder pattern of fever unless gastrointestinal or urinary tract infections are suspected.

Option C) Bone Marrow Aspirate:

  • Bone marrow aspirate is an invasive procedure that involves collecting a sample of bone marrow from the patient's bone.
  • It is used in various clinical scenarios, including the evaluation of prolonged or undiagnosed fever.
  • Bone marrow cultures can detect pathogens that have entered the bloodstream and reached the bone marrow, making it a valuable tool for diagnosing infections that may not be readily detected in peripheral blood.
  • In some cases, bone marrow aspirate can provide a more sensitive diagnostic approach, especially when other cultures, like blood cultures, may be negative.

Option D) Duodenal Aspirate:

  • Duodenal aspirate may be collected for various diagnostic purposes, including the evaluation of gastrointestinal infections.
  • It is typically used to detect infections or abnormalities in the upper gastrointestinal tract, such as infections with Helicobacter pylori.
  • Duodenal aspirates can be valuable for diagnosing specific gastrointestinal infections, but they are not typically the first-line investigation for patients with a step ladder pattern of fever, as other sources of infection are usually explored first.

In summary, the choice of which culture to perform depends on the clinical presentation and suspected source of infection. While blood cultures are commonly used for fever of unknown origin, bone marrow aspirate cultures may offer higher sensitivity in certain cases, especially when other cultures are negative and an underlying infection is suspected. Stool and urine cultures are essential for diagnosing gastrointestinal and urinary tract infections, respectively, and duodenal aspirates are specific to upper gastrointestinal evaluations.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd edition, page 298

questions.text: Most correct about hapten is-
questions.solution:
Hapten is an incomplete antigen which in combination with carriers proteins becomes complete antigen (immunogenic).

Epitope is antibody Binding site on antigen and simple haptens cannot perpetuate.

So most correct about Hapten is that they require carriers for antibody production.

Reference: Ananthanarayan 10th ed Pg 89

questions.text: Bence jones proteins are best described as-
questions.solution:
1. A Bence Jones protein is a monoclonal globulin protein or immunoglobulin light chain found in the urine, with a molecular weight of 22-24 kDa. Detection of Bence Jones protein may be suggestive of multiple myeloma or Waldenström's macroglobulinemia.
  2. Bence jones proteins are light chains of immunoglobulins so may occur as Lambda or Kappa forms, but in any other patient the chain is either Kappa or Lambda, never both.

questions.text: A young boy had a flea bite while working in a wheat grain godown. After 5 days he developed fever and had axillary lymphadenopathy. A smear was sent to the laboratory to perform a specific staining. Which one of the following staining method would help in the identification of the suspected pathogen:
questions.solution:
The most likely disease to be caused by the flea bite in a young boy is PLAGUE caused by YERSINIA PESTIS in which we do flea index or cheopic index and this smear is stained with WAYSON stain

Reference: Ananthanarayan 10th ed Pg 329

questions.text: You are posted in the dermatology department as an intern and a 56 year old female presented to dermatology OPD with complaints of hyperpigmented lesions in axilla. On wood's lamp examination a characteristic coral red fluorescence was seen. What would be the most likely causative organism responsible for a patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
Minutissimum: It causes a localized infection of skin (axilla and groin), called 'erythrasma'. It is a lipophilic Corynebacterium, can be grown readily in media containing 20% fetal calf serum. On Wood's lamp examination, erythrasma lesion emits coral red color.

Tenuis: It has been associated with Trichomycosis axillaris, characterized by the formation of pigmented nodules, around axillary and pubic hair shafts.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd edition, page no: 604

choices.text: Gamma, alpha hemolysin and PV toxin

questions.text: What constitutes the synergohymenotropic toxin in staphylococcus aureus?
questions.solution:
• Synergohymenotropic toxins: γ-hemolysin and PV toxin are called synergohymenotropic toxins. Because they are not active individually, but in combination, they are capable of producing hemolytic and leucocidal activity.
  • aureus produces four distinct hemolysins - α, β, γ and δ hemolysins. They are membrane damaging toxins, act on red blood cells (RBCs) leading to hemolysis. They exhibit various actions such as dermonecrotic, cytotoxic, neurotoxic and leukocidal activities.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd edition, page no: 512

questions.text:
A 3 year old child presented to OPD with complaints of fever, sore throat, tongue appearing like a strawberry and rash which feels like sandpaper. You are asked to take a throat swab which was sent for culture. When you go to collect the report the attending microbiologist shows you the following picture.

Identify the type of hemolysis seen in this picture and it is due to which virulence factor.
questions.solution:
Let's go through each option and provide a detailed justification for each:

Option A) Alpha hemolysis: Streptolysin B

  • Alpha hemolysis is seen as a greenish discoloration around colonies on blood agar plates. It is typically associated with some streptococcal species, like Streptococcus pneumoniae.
  • Streptolysin O is not associated with alpha hemolysis. Instead, Streptolysin O is responsible for beta hemolysis in Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A Streptococcus).

Option B) Beta hemolysis: Streptolysin

  • Beta hemolysis is the complete lysis of red blood cells around bacterial colonies on blood agar plates, creating a clear zone.
  • Streptolysin, which includes both Streptolysin O and Streptolysin S, is responsible for beta hemolysis. In the case of Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A Streptococcus), it is primarily Streptolysin O that causes beta hemolysis.

Option C) Alpha hemolysis: Serum opacity factor

  • Alpha hemolysis is not typically associated with a virulence factor called "serum opacity factor." Instead, alpha hemolysis is often seen with Streptococcus pneumoniae, which releases hydrogen peroxide and pneumolysin as virulence factors.

Option D) Gamma hemolysis: esterase

  • Gamma hemolysis is the term used when there is no hemolysis or discoloration of the agar around bacterial colonies. There are no virulence factors involved in gamma hemolysis because it represents a lack of hemolysis.
  • Esterase is not typically associated with hemolysis or the virulence of Streptococcus pyogenes.

To summarise, Option B (Beta hemolysis: Streptolysin) is the correct choice because it aligns with the clinical presentation of scarlet fever caused by Streptococcus pyogenes, which exhibits beta hemolysis primarily due to Streptolysin O. The other options do not correspond to the specific characteristics of this infection or the virulence factors involved.

Hemolysis on blood agar is because of Streptolysin present in the bacteria.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd edition, page no:521

questions.text: Serum sickness is which type of hypersensitivity reaction?
questions.solution:
• Serum sickness in humans is a reaction to proteins in antiserum derived from a non-human animal source, occurring 5-10 days after exposure.
  • It is a type of hypersensitivity, specifically immune complex hypersensitivity (type III).
  • The term serum sickness-like reaction (SSLR) is occasionally used to refer to similar illnesses that arise from the introduction of certain non-protein substances, such as penicillin.
  • Signs and symptoms can take as long as 14 days after exposure to appear, and may include signs and symptoms commonly associated with hypersensitivity or infections.
    • rashes
    • itching
    • joint pain (arthralgia), especially finger and toe joints
    • fever, as high as 40 °C (104 °F) and usually appears before rash
    • lymphadenopathy (swelling of lymph nodes), particularly near the site of injection, head and neck
    • malaise
    • hypotension (decreased blood pressure)
    • splenomegaly (enlarged spleen)
    • glomerulonephritis
    • protein in the urine
    • blood in the urine
    • shock
  • With discontinuation of the offending agent(s), symptoms usually disappear within 4-5 days.
  • Corticosteroids, antihistamines, and analgesics are the main line of treatment. The choice depends on the severity of the reaction.
  • Use of plasmapheresis has also been described.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology 10th edition Chapter 16, Pg 164-168

questions.text: An example of type I hypersensitivity is:
questions.solution:
a) Lepromin test: Type 4 Hypersensitivity

b) Tuberculin test: Type 4 Hypersensitivity

c) Casoni's test: Type 1 Hypersensitivity

d) Arthus reaction: Type 3 Hypersensitivity

Examples of Type I Hypersensitivity:

  • Experiments:
    • P-K reaction
    • Schultz Dale phenomenon
    • Theobald smith phenomenon
  • Systemic anaphylaxis
  • Localized anaphylaxis (atopy) such as:
    • Allergic rhinitis (or hay fever)
    • Asthma
    • Food allergy
    • Atopic urticarial
    • Atopic dermatitis (allergic eczema)
    • Drug allergy
    • Wheal and flare reaction.
  • Parasitic diseases:
    • Tropical Pulmonary Eosinophilia (TPE)
    • Loeffler's pneumonia (Ascaris)
    • Ground itch (Hookworm)
    • Leakage of hydatid fluid
    • Cercarial dermatitis/swimmer's itch (Schistosoma).
  • Parasitic tests:
    • Casoni test (hydatid disease)

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology 10th edition Chapter 16, Pg 164-168

choices.text: Selective medium and differentiates between LF and LNF.
Promotes growth of Candida and Staphylococcus spp.

questions.text: Cystine lactose enzyme deficient medium CLED is preferred over McConkey agar in UTI because:
questions.solution:
A) Prevents swarming of Proteus is the correct answer.

Cystine Lactose Electrolyte Deficient (CLED) medium is preferred over McConkey agar in urinary tract infection (UTI) testing for the following reasons:

Prevents swarming of Proteus:

  • Proteus species can swarm on agar plates, which means they exhibit rapid and extensive movement across the surface of the medium, making it difficult to interpret bacterial growth and colony characteristics.
  • CLED agar contains less agar than MacConkey agar and lacks the specific nutrients that support swarming. This inhibits the swarming behaviour of Proteus, allowing for better visualization and identification of other urinary pathogens.

B) Selective medium and differentiates between LF and LNF (Lactose Fermenters and Non-Lactose Fermenters):

  • CLED medium is not primarily a selective medium but a differential one. It allows for the differentiation between lactose-fermenting bacteria (LF) and non-lactose fermenters (LNF) based on the colour change of colonies.
  • McConkey agar is also a differential medium that can differentiate between LF and LNF based on the colour change and the ability to ferment lactose, but it's more commonly used for testing the ability to ferment lactose in enteric bacteria.

C) Promotes growth of Pseudomonas spp.:

  • CLED medium is not specific for promoting the growth of Pseudomonas species. Pseudomonas species have specific growth requirements that are not met by CLED agar.

D) Promotes growth of Candida and Staphylococcus spp.:

  • CLED medium is not intended for promoting the growth of Candida or Staphylococcus species. It is primarily used for culturing and differentiating urinary pathogens, especially Enterobacteriaceae.

In summary, CLED medium is preferred over McConkey agar in UTI testing mainly because it prevents the swarming behaviour of Proteus species, allowing for better identification and differentiation of other urinary pathogens.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology 12th edition pg 29

questions.text: The discovery of 'gene transformation' came from the study (as shown in the image) of one of the following bacteria:
questions.solution:
• Transformation is the process of random uptake of free or naked DNA fragment from environment by a bacterial cell and incorporation into its chromosome in a heritable form.
  • The Griffith experiment (1928) on mice using Streptococcus pneumoniae (pneumococci) strains provided the direct evidence of transformation.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology 10th edition Chapter 7, Pg 59

questions.text: Hair perforation test is positive in
questions.solution:
Hair perforation test is positive in trichophyton mentagrophytes in which hair is plucked from infected site and put into moist condition and after 2-3 days, wedge formation occurs indicating hair perforation phenomenon (WEDGE)

Reference: Ananthanarayan, 10th ed, Pg 603

questions.text: Equipment shown in the image is best sterilised by:
questions.solution:
Equipment shown in the image is a Heart lung machine.

Heart lung machines, respirators and dental equipments are best sterilised by Ethylene oxide.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 12th Edition, Page Number - 133.

questions.text: Which mode of transmission of HIV has the maximum risk of transmission?
questions.solution:
• Blood transfusion is the least common mode of transmission but it has the maximum risk.
  • On the other hand, heterosexual intercourse is the most common mode of transmission but it has a minimal risk of transmission.
  • Saliva contains inhibitory substances that prevent transmission of HIV.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd edition, page 326

questions.text: Warthin finkeldy giant cells are seen in:
questions.solution:
• Cytopathic effect in measles may be observed after 7-10 days of inoculation into cell lines characterized by-multinucleated giant cells (warthin-Finkeldey cells) containing both intranuclear and intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies.
  • Koplik spots are pathogonomic to measles.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's textbook of microbiology, 10th edition, page no 518

questions.text: What will be the serological profile of a patient infected with acute HBV during its maximum infectivity period?
questions.solution: Reference: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter: 17, Pg: 261

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman comes for annual pelvic examination and Pap smear. A photomicrograph of cervical cells from the Pap smear specimen is shown. Cells similar to the one indicated by the arrow are most likely to be seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
• The cell indicated by the arrow is a dysplastic squamous epithelial cell with an enlarged, irregular nucleus and hyperchromasia.

These are features of koilocytes.

  • Koilocytes are pathognomonic of an infection with HPV.
  • Condylomata acuminata, like cervical dysplasia, are caused by an infection with HPV and can therefore present with koilocytes on histopathology.
  • Condylomata acuminata are typically associated with HPV strains 6 and 11.
  • Other manifestations of HPV infection include vulvar and vaginal intraepithelial neoplasia, as well as skin warts (verruca vulgaris) and plantar warts.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd Edition, Page Number 550

questions.text: Identify the correct organism causing this type of presentation.
questions.solution:
• This pearly, flesh-colored rash with a central umbilication occurs due to Molluscum contagiosum virus (Poxvirus family).
  • It is usually asymptomatic, but maybe associated with pruritus or tenderness.
  • On histology, it shows Molluscum bodies (aka Henderson-Peterson bodies) which are large cells with granular eosinophilic cytoplasm that contain accumulated virions, as shown in image below.
  • It is self-limiting in nature, heals by itself or Ritonavir can be given in severe cases.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd Edition, Page Number 550

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents with 2-day history of progressively blurred vision. He also reports seeing flashing lights in his visual field. Examination shows right conjunctival injection. Visual acuity is 20/20 in the left eye and 20/100 in the right eye. Funduscopic examination of the right eye is shown. His CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 46/mm3. Which of the following is responsible for this patient's eye condition?
questions.solution:
• Fundoscopy in this patient, who's depressed CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is almost certainly secondary to infection with the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), shows fluffy, hemorrhagic, perivascular retinal lesions that radiate out from the optic disc (pizza-pie appearance).
  • These symptoms and findings are characteristic of cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis.
  • Valgancyclovir is the first-line therapy for CMV retinitis, a condition that can cause blurring, vision loss, floaters, and photopsia (flashing lights).
  • Other first-line systemic therapies include ganciclovir, foscarnet, and cidofovir.
  • Patients with acutely sight-threatening disease (e.g., lesions < 1.5 mm from the fovea or adjacent to the optic nerve head) should also receive intravitreal therapy with ganciclovir or foscarnet.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd Edition, Page Number 550

questions.text: Identify the condition:
questions.solution:
Herpes zoster Opthalmicus

  • this is due to reactivation
  • Single sided lesion due to T3-L3 dermatome involvement
  • ophthalmic branch of trigeminal name is involved.

Herpes zoster oticus. (Ramsay hunt Syndrome)

Bell's palsy + vesicle over External auditory canal, tympanic memberane, cheeks.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's textbook of microbiology, 10th edition, page no 478, 479

questions.text: Oakley-Fulthorpe procedure is:
questions.solution:
Solutions: Various immunodiffusion test

  • Single diffusion in one dimension - Oudin procedure
  • Double diffusion in one dimension - Oakley fulthorpe procedure
  • Single diffusion in two dimensions - Radial immunodiffusion
  • Double diffusion in two dimensions - Ouchterlony procedure

Reference: Ananthanarayan, 10th ed, Pg 108
